block.p: Tally Last Week in Connecticut, New Jersey and New York.

1. Federal Role: Vote on an amendment to Medicare legislation that would strengthen the role of the federal government in delivering a new prescription drug benefit. The proposed bill would offer new prescription drug coverage to Medicare beneficiaries, but it would be provided, by and large, through private insurers. Rejected 58 to 37, June 18.
Tally Last Week in Connecticut, New Jersey and New York.

1. Federal Role: Vote on an amendment to Medicare legislation that would strengthen the role of the federal government in delivering a new prescription drug benefit. The proposed bill would offer new prescription drug coverage to Medicare beneficiaries, but it would be provided, by and large, through private insurers. Rejected 58 to 37, June 18.

2. Premiums: Vote on an amendment to Medicare legislation to limit the premiums that could be charged for the new prescription drug benefits so that the premiums could not exceed the national average by more than 10 percent. Rejected 56 to 39, June 19. 3. Generic Drugs: Vote on an amendment to Medicare legislation that would give consumers swifter access to low-cost copies of brand-name prescription drugs. Approved 94 to 1, June 19. 4. Prescription Drugs From Canada: Vote on an amendment to Medicare legislation that would allow American pharmacists to buy prescription drugs in Canada, where their prices are lower, and resell them in the United States. Approved 62 to 28, June 20.
KEY: (A) Absent or did not vote; (P) Present.

1. Estate Tax: Vote to permanently end the federal estate tax, which is currently scheduled to phase out in 2010 and then revert to its old top rate of 60 percent in 2011. Approved 264 to 163, June 18.
Connecticut 1. Larson (D): Nay 2. Simmons (R): Yea 3. DeLauro (D): Nay 4. Shays (R): Yea 5. Johnson (R): Nay

New Jersey 1. Andrews (D): Nay 2. LoBiondo (R): Yea 3. Saxton (R): Yea 4. Smith (R): Yea 5. Garrett (R): Yea 6. Pallone (D): Nay 7. Ferguson (R): Yea 8. Pascrell (D): Nay 9. Rothman (D): Nay 10. Payne (D): Nay 11. Frelinghuysen (R): Yea 12. Holt (D): Nay 13. Menendez (D): Nay

New York 1. Bishop (D): Nay 2. Israel (D): Yea 3. King (R): Yea 4. McCarthy (D): Yea 5. Ackerman (D): Nay 6. Meeks (D): Nay 7. Crowley (D): Nay 8. Nadler (D): A 9. Weiner (D): Nay 10. Towns (D): Nay 11. Owens (D): Nay 12. Vel√°zquez (D): Nay 13. Fossella (R): Yea 14. Maloney (D): Nay 15. Rangel (D): Nay 16. Serrano (D): Nay 17. Engel (D): Nay 18. Lowey (D): Nay 19. Kelly (R): Yea 20. Sweeney (R): Yea 21. McNulty (D): Nay 22. Hinchey (D): Nay 23. McHugh (R): Yea 24. Boehlert (R): Yea 25. Walsh (R): Yea 26. Reynolds (R): Yea 27. Quinn (R): Yea 28. Slaughter (D): Nay 29. Houghton (R): Nay
KEY: (A) Absent or did not vote; (P) Present.

Correction: June 26, 2003, Thursday The Votes in Congress chart on Sunday gave incorrect positions in some copies for Senators Jon S. Corzine and Frank R. Lautenberg of New Jersey and Hillary Rodham Clinton and Charles E. Schumer of New York on a failed Democratic amendment to a bill creating a Medicare prescription drug benefit. They voted yea, not nay. The amendment would have strengthened the federal government's role in delivering the benefit.

The Votes in Congress chart on Sunday gave incorrect positions in some copies for Senators Jon S. Corzine and Frank R. Lautenberg of New Jersey and Hillary Rodham Clinton and Charles E. Schumer of New York on a failed Democratic amendment to a bill creating a Medicare prescription drug benefit. They voted yea, not nay. The amendment would have strengthened the federal government's role in delivering the benefit.
